articles.headline: Looking Out for Yourself With Disability Insurance
articles.snippet: As some employers push more of the onus for disability insurance onto their employees, here’s what you need to know to buy it on your own.
articles.abstract: As some employers push more of the onus for disability insurance onto their employees, here’s what you need to know to buy it on your own.
articles.lead_paragraph: In case anyone has forgotten, we’re all basically on our own here in personal finance land.

articles.headline: Nations Trying to Stop Their Citizens From Going to Middle East to Fight for ISIS
articles.snippet: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
articles.abstract: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — France wants more power to block its citizens from leaving the country, while Britain is weighing whether to stop more of its citizens from coming home. Tunisia is debating measures to make it a criminal offense to help jihadist fighters travel to Syria and Iraq, while Russia has outlawed enlisting in armed groups that are “contradictory to Russian policy.”

articles.headline: After Breach, JPMorgan Still Seeks to Determine Extent of Attack
articles.snippet: Over two months, hackers gained entry to dozens of the bank’s servers, said three people with knowledge of the bank’s investigation into the episode.
articles.abstract: Over two months, hackers gained entry to dozens of the bank’s servers, said three people with knowledge of the bank’s investigation into the episode.
articles.lead_paragraph: The headache caused by the attack on JPMorgan Chase’s computer network this summer may not go away anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Europeans Bracing for Netflix
articles.snippet: As Netflix prepares to start streaming in six European countries next week, some politicians and rival businesses there are assailing the company over issues like competition and taxes.
articles.abstract: As Netflix prepares to start streaming in six European countries next week, some politicians and rival businesses there are assailing the company over issues like competition and taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — With Netflix poised to make its debut in six European countries next week, the expansion of that online streaming giant’s international territory is stirring a mix of anticipation, anxiety and “House of Cards”-style political intrigue.

articles.headline: Adapting Listerine to a Global Market
articles.snippet: With products like Listerine Zero, popular where alcohol is forbidden, and Green Tea Listerine, big in Asia, Johnson & Johnson is trying to appeal to foreign tastes.
articles.abstract: With products like Listerine Zero, popular where alcohol is forbidden, and Green Tea Listerine, big in Asia, Johnson & Johnson is trying to appeal to foreign tastes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORRIS PLAINS, N.J. — Walking into the Listerine “stink lab” is like stepping into a gigantic human mouth.

articles.headline: New Sanctions to Stall Exxon’s Arctic Oil Plans
articles.snippet: The United States government took aim at Exxon’s project in the Arctic Ocean, ordering American companies to cut off exports to Russian oil exploration within 14 days.
articles.abstract: The United States government took aim at Exxon’s project in the Arctic Ocean, ordering American companies to cut off exports to Russian oil exploration within 14 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Exxon Mobil’s ambitions in Russia appear to have been dashed, at least until the Ukraine crisis is resolved.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: U.S. Scientists See Long Fight Against Ebola
articles.snippet: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more and could infect hundreds of thousands, say scientists mapping its spread for the American government.
articles.abstract: The Ebola outbreak in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more and could infect hundreds of thousands, say scientists mapping its spread for the American government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The deadly Ebola outbreak sweeping across three countries in West Africa is likely to last 12 to 18 months more, much longer than anticipated, and could infect hundreds of thousands of people before it is brought under control, say scientists mapping its spread for the federal government.

articles.headline: From White Knight to Thief
articles.snippet: Wall Street crime, 1930s style: the astonishing downfall of the financier Richard Whitney, who helped shore up the market at the start of the ’29 crash.
articles.abstract: Wall Street crime, 1930s style: the astonishing downfall of the financier Richard Whitney, who helped shore up the market at the start of the ’29 crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 1941, Richard Whitney, the former financier and New York Stock Exchange president, emerged from prison at Sing Sing, on parole after serving three years of a five- to 10-year sentence for grand larceny.

articles.headline: Caesars’ Debt: A Game of Dealer’s Choice
articles.snippet: Caesars Entertainment offered some of its debt holders an attractive deal — and other holders are angry about the implications.
articles.abstract: Caesars Entertainment offered some of its debt holders an attractive deal — and other holders are angry about the implications.
articles.lead_paragraph: The house always wins. That’s worth remembering when you’re in a casino. It also seems to be true for some people who hold Caesars Entertainment debt.

articles.headline: Trying to Hit the Brake on Texting While Driving
articles.snippet: People keep texting when they’re behind the wheel, so an engineer has found a technological solution. The problem: He can’t do it on his own.
articles.abstract: People keep texting when they’re behind the wheel, so an engineer has found a technological solution. The problem: He can’t do it on his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: People know they shouldn’t text and drive. Overwhelmingly, they tell pollsters that doing so is unacceptable and dangerous, and yet they do it anyway. They can’t resist. So safety advocates and public officials have called for a technological solution that does an end run around free will and prevents people from texting in the first place.

articles.headline: Paths to War, Then and Now, Haunt Obama
articles.snippet: Before recently announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: Before recently announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just hours before announcing an escalated campaign against Islamic extremists last week, President Obama privately reflected on another time when a president weighed military action in the Middle East — the frenzied weeks leading up to the American invasion of Iraq a decade ago.

articles.headline: Back to the Slums of His Youth, to Defuse the Ebola Time Bomb
articles.snippet: Liberia remains desperately short on everything needed to halt the spread of Ebola, but an epidemiologist is working block by block to fill a crucial need: the support of residents.
articles.abstract: Liberia remains desperately short on everything needed to halt the spread of Ebola, but an epidemiologist is working block by block to fill a crucial need: the support of residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — The girl in the pink shirt lay motionless on a sidewalk, flat on her stomach, an orange drink next to her, unfinished. People gathered on the other side of the street, careful to keep their distance.

articles.headline: ISIS Video Shows Execution of David Cawthorne Haines, British Aid Worker
articles.snippet: A video released by the group shows the aid worker kneeling in a desert landscape that looks identical to where two American journalists were killed by the group in the past month. Moments later, he is beheaded.
articles.abstract: A video released by the group shows the aid worker kneeling in a desert landscape that looks identical to where two American journalists were killed by the group in the past month. Moments later, he is beheaded.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Islamic State in Iraq and Syria released a video Saturday of the third beheading of a foreign hostage, a British aid worker. The execution was a clear message to Britain, a vital ally of the United States as it builds an international coalition to target the militant group, which has made stunning advances across Syria and northern Iraq in recent months.
articles.byline: By Rukmini Callimachi and Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura

articles.headline: Building Legacy, Obama Reshapes Appellate Bench
articles.snippet: After a change in Senate filibuster rules, judges appointed by Democrats now hold a majority of seats on the United States Courts of Appeals, a tilt that has far-reaching consequences for President Obama’s legacy.
articles.abstract: After a change in Senate filibuster rules, judges appointed by Democrats now hold a majority of seats on the United States Courts of Appeals, a tilt that has far-reaching consequences for President Obama’s legacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats have reversed the partisan imbalance on the federal appeals courts that long favored conservatives, a little-noticed shift with far-reaching consequences for the law and President Obama’s legacy.

articles.headline: Arab Nations Offer to Fight ISIS From Air
articles.snippet: American officials have made it clear they do not want the airstrikes to get ahead of the ground action against ISIS, which they said would take time to mass.
articles.abstract: American officials have made it clear they do not want the airstrikes to get ahead of the ground action against ISIS, which they said would take time to mass.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Sunday that “several” Arab nations had offered to join in airstrikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, but any sustained military campaign does not appear imminent, and is likely to require an even more significant commitment from other nations and fighting forces in the region.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: IAC, Owner of Match and Tinder, Makes Moves in Online Dating
articles.snippet: Under Barry Diller, IAC/InterActiveCorp has been increasing its presence in an online market that has become increasingly crowded.
articles.abstract: Under Barry Diller, IAC/InterActiveCorp has been increasing its presence in an online market that has become increasingly crowded.
articles.lead_paragraph: IAC/InterActiveCorp has always had a thing for online dating. But now things are getting really serious.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: In Florida Student Assaults, an Added Burden on Accusers
articles.snippet: Last year, the Tallahassee police’s handling of a rape accusation against Jameis Winston drew attention to its failure to adequately investigate. Now, an examination shows a pattern to the handling of such complaints.
articles.abstract: Last year, the Tallahassee police’s handling of a rape accusation against Jameis Winston drew attention to its failure to adequately investigate. Now, an examination shows a pattern to the handling of such complaints.
articles.lead_paragraph: After downing a double dose of NyQuil to fight a cold, the young woman woke in a man’s dormitory room with a vague memory of someone being on top of her, but no recollection of sexual contact. Three days later she found a condom in her vagina. She repeatedly confronted the man, who insisted that nothing had happened, and his roommate, who had told her he saw them having sex, then said he was joking.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Alibaba’s Link to Elite Military Family Is Etched in Stone
articles.snippet: An ancestral tablet at a Chinese tomb shows how an executive who profited from Alibaba’s acquisition of her company is connected to a family of prominent generals.
articles.abstract: An ancestral tablet at a Chinese tomb shows how an executive who profited from Alibaba’s acquisition of her company is connected to a family of prominent generals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Perched on a steep hillside in Changshou township lies the modest family tomb of a military dynasty, overgrown with tall grass and lined with cheap white tiles.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: With Tech Taking Over in Schools, Worries Rise
articles.snippet: Parent groups and privacy advocates are challenging the practices of an industry built on data collection, and California has passed wide-ranging legislation protecting students’ personal information.
articles.abstract: Parent groups and privacy advocates are challenging the practices of an industry built on data collection, and California has passed wide-ranging legislation protecting students’ personal information.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a New York state elementary school, teachers can use a behavior-monitoring app to compile information on which children have positive attitudes and which act out. In Georgia, some high school cafeterias are using a biometric identification system to let students pay for lunch by scanning the palms of their hands at the checkout line. And across the country, school sports teams are using social media sites for athletes to exchange contact information and game locations.

articles.headline: In Latest Volley Against Amazon, Hachette’s Writers Target Its Board
articles.snippet: Authors United, a group of Hachette writers and allies, is appealing to Amazon’s board to consider their reputation in the battle over e-book pricing.
articles.abstract: Authors United, a group of Hachette writers and allies, is appealing to Amazon’s board to consider their reputation in the battle over e-book pricing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amazon is at war with Hachette, and it sometimes seems as if it has always been that way.

articles.headline: The Magic in Apple’s Devices? The Heart
articles.snippet: Apple’s ability to seize the moment and preoccupy the press is without peer.
articles.abstract: Apple’s ability to seize the moment and preoccupy the press is without peer.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the last seismic Apple announcement, in 2010, I was at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts in San Francisco as Steve Jobs unveiled the iPad, a device he said was so singular it would create its own landing strip.

articles.headline: Conservative Experiment Faces Revolt in Reliably Red Kansas
articles.snippet: Some of Kansas’ staunchest Republicans have found some of Gov. Sam Brownback’s measures to be too far to the right, and have endorsed Paul Davis, the Democratic candidate.
articles.abstract: Some of Kansas’ staunchest Republicans have found some of Gov. Sam Brownback’s measures to be too far to the right, and have endorsed Paul Davis, the Democratic candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUTCHINSON, Kan. — In his 40 years living in Kansas, Konrad Hastings cannot remember voting for a Democrat. He is the type who agonizes over big purchases, trying to save as much money as possible. He is against stricter gun laws, opposes abortion in most cases and prefers less government involvement in his life.

articles.headline: Regulator Slow to Respond to Deadly Vehicle Defects
articles.snippet: An investigation by The New York Times has found that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration frequently has been slow to identify problems, tentative to act and reluctant to employ its full legal powers against companies.
articles.abstract: An investigation by The New York Times has found that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration frequently has been slow to identify problems, tentative to act and reluctant to employ its full legal powers against companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors published an article in February on its Chevrolet website trumpeting an achievement certain to help sell a lot of cars.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout, Danielle Ivory and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Line by Line, E-Books Turn Poet-Friendly
articles.snippet: Digital publishers have gotten better at creating e-books that preserve a poet’s meticulous formatting, but some writers are still leery of surrendering their work to the digital realm.
articles.abstract: Digital publishers have gotten better at creating e-books that preserve a poet’s meticulous formatting, but some writers are still leery of surrendering their work to the digital realm.
articles.lead_paragraph: When John Ashbery, the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet, first learned that the digital editions of his poetry looked nothing like the print version, he was stunned. There were no line breaks, and the stanzas had been jammed together into a block of text that looked like prose. The careful architecture of his poems had been leveled.

articles.headline: Maker of Costly Hepatitis C Drug Sovaldi Strikes Deal on Generics for Poor Countries
articles.snippet: The agreements between Gilead Sciences and seven Indian firms seek to provide treatment to those infected in 91 developing nations.
articles.abstract: The agreements between Gilead Sciences and seven Indian firms seek to provide treatment to those infected in 91 developing nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The maker of one of the costliest drugs in the world announced on Monday that it had struck deals with seven generic drug makers in India to sell lower-cost versions of the medicine — a $1,000-a-pill hepatitis C treatment — in poorer countries.

articles.headline: General Motors Defect Now Faulted in 19 Deaths
articles.snippet: The tally, announced on Monday by the lawyer Kenneth Feinberg, is higher than the 13 fatalities the automaker has linked to a defective ignition system.
articles.abstract: The tally, announced on Monday by the lawyer Kenneth Feinberg, is higher than the 13 fatalities the automaker has linked to a defective ignition system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The death toll from General Motors’ faulty ignition switch is rising.
